revision.text:
[[File:Illustrerad Verldshistoria band I Ill 012.jpg|thumbnail|Ancient Egyptian wrestling.]] [[Wrestling]] and [[grappling]] sports have a long and complicated history, stretching into prehistoric times. Many traditional forms survive, grouped under the term [[folk wrestling]]. More formal systems have been codified in various forms of [[martial arts]] worldwide, where [[grappling]] techniques form a significant subset of [[Unarmed combat|unarmed fighting]] (complemented by [[Strike (attack)|striking techniques]]).
The modern '''history of wrestling''' begins with a rise of popularity in the 19th century, which led to the development of the modern sports of [[Greco-Roman wrestling]] on the European continent and of [[freestyle wrestling]] and [[collegiate wrestling]] in Great Britain and the United States, respectively. These sports enjoyed enormous popularity at the turning of the 20th century. In the 1920s, show wrestling as a form of [[sports entertainment]], now known as [[professional wrestling]], separated from competitive sport wrestling, now known as [[amateur wrestling]].
==Antiquity== {{further|wrestling mythology}} [[Image:Beni Hassan tomb 15 wrestling detail.jpg|thumb|300px|Detail of the wrestling scenes in tomb 15 ([[Baqet III]]) at Beni Hasan.]] Wrestling as a type of [[mock combat]] and [[display behaviour]] among males has anthropological roots, and is also seen in non-human [[Great ape|Great Apes]]. Its documented history however necessarily begins with the history of pictorial representations. Cave paintings in the [[Bayankhongor Province]] of [[Mongolia]] dating back to Neolithic age of 7000 BC show grappling of two naked men and surrounded by crowds.<ref name="sfgate">Wrestling, archery and horse racing contests in Genghis Khan's ancient capital, Karakorum. Julie Skurdenis, Special to The Chronicle. Sunday, March 27, 2005.[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2005/03/27/TRGNHBUA801.DTL]</ref> {{Irrelevant citation|date=July 2015|reason=article does not mention cave paintings}} In the [[Ancient Near East]], forms of [[belt wrestling]] were popular from earliest times.<ref>‘’Encyclopædia Britannica’’,1981,{{ISBN|0-85229-378-X}},p.1025. Images of wrestling, have been found on cylinder seals and a copper [[statuette]], dated 3000 BC.</ref> A carving on a stone slabe showing three pairs of wrestlers was dated to around 3000 BC.<ref name="Blanchard1995">{{cite book|author=Kendall Blanchard|title=The Anthropology of Sport: An Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aGeLoS1pWA4C&pg=PA99|accessdate=26 September 2012|year=1995|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-89789-330-5|pages=99–}}</ref> A cast [[Bronze]] figurine,<ref name="Inc1938">{{cite book|author=Time Inc|title=LIFE|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gE8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA59|accessdate=26 September 2012|date=15 August 1938|publisher=Time Inc|pages=59–|issn=0024-3019}}</ref> (perhaps the base of a [[vase]]) has been found at [[Khafaji]] in [[Iraq]] that shows two figures in a wrestling hold that dates to around 2600 BC. The statue is one of the earliest depictions of sport and is housed in the [[National Museum of Iraq]].<ref name="Baṣmahʹjī1975">{{cite book|author=Faraj Baṣmahʹjī|title=Treasures of the Iraq Museum|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dbJtAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=26 September 2012|year=1975|publisher=Al-Jumhuriya Press}}</ref><ref name="Romano1993">{{cite book|author=David Gilman Romano|title=Athletics and Mathematics in Archaic Corinth: The Origins of the Greek Stadion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q0gyy5JOZzIC&pg=PA10|accessdate=26 September 2012|year=1993|publisher=American Philosophical Society|isbn=978-0-87169-206-1|pages=10–}}</ref>
[[File:Egyptmotionseries.jpg|thumb|300px|An [[Egypt]]ian [[burial chamber]] [[mural]], from the tomb of [[Baqet III]] dating to around 2000 BC, showing [[wrestler]]s in action.<ref name="Newberry 1893" /><ref name="lessing">[http://www.lessing-photo.com/dispimg.asp?i=08011040+&cr=40&cl=1 Egypt Thomb]. ''Lessing Photo''. 02-15-2011.</ref>]] Portrayal of martial arts sporting in Egypt has begun by the time of the [[Ancient Egypt|5th Dynasty]] mastaba tombs at [[Saqqara, Egypt|Saqqara]], circa 2400 BC. After a boat joust scene recorded in the tomb of [[Khnumhotep and Niankhkhnum|Niankhkhnum and Khnumhotep]], who were manicurists to [[Nyuserre Ini|King Nyuserre]], six pairs of boys wrestle in the nearby tomb of Akhethotep and Ptahhotep.<ref name="Rice2001">{{cite book|last1=Rice|first1=Michael|title=Who's Who in Ancient Egypt?|date=2002|publisher=Psychology Press|location=Abingdon, UK|isbn=9780415154499}}</ref><ref name="Porter and Moss">{{cite book|last1=Porter & Moss|editor1-last=Malek|editor1-first=Jaromir|title=Topographical Bibliography III: Memphis, Part 2: Saqqara to Dahshur|date=1981|publisher=Griffith Institute|location=Oxford|pages=602, 643|edition=revised|url=http://www.griffith.ox.ac.uk/topbib/pdf/pm3-2.pdf|accessdate=9 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="Davies 1900">{{cite book|last1=Davies|first1=Norman de Garis|title=The Mastaba of Ptahhetep and Akhethetep at Saqqareh: The chapel of Ptahhetep and the hieroglyphs|date=1900|publisher=Egypt Exploration Society|location=London|pages=10–11, Plates 24, 25|url=http://digi.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/diglit/davies1900bd1|accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref>{{efn| The vizier Ptahhotep under King Isesi is buried in the complex of mastabas where the boys' games scenes occur. Davies (1900), p. 2, identifies Ptahhotep and Akhethotep as father and son, but does not say whether they are relatives of the vizier. Antiquity associated Vizier Ptahhotep's name with the Instruction of Ptahhotep, a document containing etiquette advice and philosophical reflections. However, this is first attested in Papyrus Prisse of the Middle Kingdom and Vincent Tobin assigns original composition to between latter Dynasty 6 and Dynasty 12, making it postdate Isesi by 100 to 400 years. See Tobin, "The Maxims of Phahhotep," in William Kelly Simpson (2003), ''The Literature of Ancient Egypt,'' Yale University Press, pp. 129-130. {{ISBN|978-0-300-09920-1}}}} Another early piece of evidence for wrestling in [[Egypt]] appears at 11th and 12th Dynasty [[Beni Hasan]] (2000 BC, images at right and above), where wrestling scenes in several tombs are elaborated to cover much of a wall.<ref name="Newberry 1893">{{cite book|last1=Newberry|first1=Percy|title=Beni Hasan II|date=1893|publisher=Egypt Exploration Society|location=London|pages=47, Plate 5|url=http://digi.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/diglit/newberry1893bd2}}</ref><ref name="lessing" /> During the period of the [[New Kingdom]] (1550-1070 BC), additional Egyptian artwork (often on [[frieze]]s), depicted Egyptian and Nubian wrestlers competing. Carroll notes striking similarities between these ancient depictions and those of the modern [[Nuba fighting|Nuba wrestlers]].<ref>{{Citation| last =Carroll| first =Scott T.| title = Wrestling in Ancient Nubia| journal = Journal of Sport History| volume = 15| issue = 2| pages = 121–137| date = Summer 1988| url = http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/JSH/JSH1988/JSH1502/jsh1502b.pdf|format=PDF| issn = 0094-1700 }}</ref> On the 406 wrestling pairs found in the Middle Kingdom tombs at Beni Hasan in the Nile valley, nearly all of the techniques seen in modern [[freestyle wrestling]] could be found.<ref name = 1198Poliakoff/>
Textual description of wrestling begins with the ancient classics, especially the [[Homer|Greek]] and [[Sanskrit epics|Sanskrit]] epics. The [[Mahabharata]] describes the encounter between the accomplished wrestlers [[Bhima]] and [[Jarasandha]]. [[Shuai Jiao]] is a legendary wrestling style of Chinese antiquity used by the [[Yellow Emperor]] during his fight against the rebel Chih Yiu. This early style of combat was first called ''jiao ti'' (butting with horns).<ref>{{Citation|publisher= Chinese Kuoshu Institute| url = http://www.kuoshu.co.uk/History%20-%20SJ.htm| accessdate = 2007-10-08 }} See also {{Citation| last = Peiser| first = Benny| title = Western Theories about the Origins of Sport in Ancient China| journal = Sports Historian| volume = 16| pages = 117–130| date = May 1996| issn = 1351-5462| doi = 10.1080/17460269609446397 }}</ref>
[[Greek wrestling]] was a popular form of [[martial art]] in which points were awarded for touching a competitor's back to the ground, forcing a competitor out of bounds (arena).<ref>{{Citation| last = Miller | first = Christopher| title = Submission Fighting and the Rules of Ancient Greek Wrestling| url = http://historical-pankration.com/articles_wrestling.html| accessdate = 2007-10-08 }}</ref> Three falls determined the winner. It was at least featured as a sport since the eighteenth [[Olympiad]] in 704 BC. Wrestling is described in the earliest celebrated works of [[Greek literature]], the [[Iliad]] and the [[Odyssey]].<ref name = 1191Poliakoff>{{cite book|last1=Poliakoff|first1=Michael|editor1-last=Levinson|editor1-first=David|editor2-last=Christensen|editor2-first=Karen|title=Encyclopedia of World Sport: From Ancient Times to the Present (Vol. 3)|date=1996|publisher=ABC-CLIO|location=Santa Barbara, CA|isbn=0-87436-819-7|pages=1191|chapter=Wrestling, Freestyle}}</ref> Wrestlers were also depicted in action on many vases, sculptures, and coins, as well as in other literature. Other cultures featured wrestling at royal or religious celebrations, but the ancient Greeks structured their style of wrestling as part of a tournament where a single winner emerged from a pool of competitors.<ref name = 1198Poliakoff>{{cite book|last1=Poliakoff|first1=Michael|editor1-last=Levinson|editor1-first=David|editor2-last=Christensen|editor2-first=Karen|title=Encyclopedia of World Sport: From Ancient Times to the Present (Vol. 3)|date=1996|publisher=ABC-CLIO|location=Santa Barbara, CA|isbn=0-87436-819-7|pages=1189|chapter=Wrestling, Freestyle}}</ref> Late Greek tradition also stated that [[Plato]] was known for wrestling in the [[Isthmian games]].<ref name = 1193Poliakoff>{{cite book|last1=Poliakoff|first1=Michael|editor1-last=Levinson|editor1-first=David|editor2-last=Christensen|editor2-first=Karen|title=Encyclopedia of World Sport: From Ancient Times to the Present (Vol. 3)|date=1996|publisher=ABC-CLIO|location=Santa Barbara, CA|isbn=0-87436-819-7|pages=1193|chapter=Wrestling, Freestyle}}</ref>
This continued into the Hellenistic period. [[Ptolemy II]] and [[Ptolemy III]] of Egypt were both depicted in art as victorious wrestlers. After the Roman conquest of the Greeks, [[Greek wrestling]] was absorbed by the Roman culture and became [[Roman Wrestling]] during the period of the [[Roman Empire]] (510 BC to AD 500).{{Citation needed|date=March 2007}} By the eighth century, the Byzantine emperor [[Basil I]], according to court historians, won in wrestling against a boastful wrestler from [[Bulgaria]].<ref name = 1193Poliakoff/>
== Viking Age Scandinavia ==
[[Glíma]] is the name of the [[Scandinavia]]n [[martial art]] used by the [[Viking]]s. The word glíma in [[Old Norse]] means glimpse or flash, which describes the systems techniques. Glima as a sport covers several types of Scandinavian [[folk wrestling]]: [[Lausatök]], Hryggspenna, and Brokartök. Glima was the most widespread sport in the [[Viking Age]] (800AD-c. 1050), and was practiced by men and women of all ages. Wherever Vikings gathered, Glima was a big part of the entertainment. Glima was so important for Viking society that their most popular god, [[Thor]], was also the Viking god of wrestling. ''Glima'' is first mentioned in 9th century Viking poetry about the Norse god Thor and his journey to Utgards-Loki, where [[Elli]] defeats Thor in a [[wrestling]] match. Glima in Iceland is almost unchanged since Viking times. The original Norwegian settlers in [[Iceland]] took Viking wrestling and the Glima combat systems with them, according to the [[Jónsbók]] law book from 1325, and the book of laws known as [[Grágás]], which refers to a collection of earlier Norwegian laws with rules for Viking wrestling.
== Medieval and Early Modern Europe == {{further|Ringen}} [[Image:Sweerts, Michael -1649- - Wrestling Match.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Michiel Sweerts]], ''Wrestling Match'', 1649.]] There is ample evidence of wrestling practiced throughout medieval Europe, both by the nobility and the lower classes. Wrestling remained popular during the Renaissance, and for much of the 16th century. In 1520 at the [[Field of the Cloth of Gold]] pageant, [[Francis I of France]] threw [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] of England in a wrestling shoes match.<ref name = 1193Poliakoff/> In [[Henry VIII]]'s kingdom, wrestling in many places was widely popular and had a long history.
The [[German school of fencing|German tradition]] has records of a number of master-''[[Ringen|Ringer]]'' of the 15th to 16th centuries specializing in unarmed combat. Unarmed combat was divided in two categories, sportive grappling or ''geselliges ringen'' and serious unarmed combat or ''kampfringen'' (where ''kampf'' is the [[Early Modern German]] term for "[[duel]]"). While sportive grappling had fixed rules that prohibited dangerous techniques, usually starting in [[grappling hold]] and ending with a [[throw (grappling)|throw]] or [[Submission (combat sports)|submission]], ''kampfringen'' can be considered a system of unarmed [[self-defense]] including [[Punch (combat)|punches]], [[joint-locks]], [[elbow strike]]s, [[chokehold]]s, [[headbutt]]s and (to a limited extent) [[kick]]s.
One of the primary men to have shaped kampfringen at the dawning of the German Renaissance appears to have been Austrian master Ott Jud. He is said to have developed a system of grappling to be used in combat, including joint breaks, arm locks and throws designed to cause serious injury. No treatise from Ott's own hand has survived, but his system is taught by several fencing masters of the later 15th century. [[Paulus Kal]] counts him among the "society of [[Liechtenauer]]", saying that he was wrestling teacher to the "lords of [[Habsburg Austria|Austria]]".<ref>''Maister ott jud der der hern von osterrich ringer gewessen yst'' ([https://books.google.com/books?id=Qq4AAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA244&dq=%22Ott+Jud%22&hl=en&ei=L98NTriaFMOV8QOSoey4Dg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=%22Ott%20Jud%22&f=false k. k. Ambraser-Sammlung], ca. 1470)</ref> (possibly under [[Frederick III, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick III]]).<ref>Welle 1993, p. 259</ref> Other treatises that contain material both on ''ringen'' and on swordsmanship include those of [[Fiore dei Liberi]] (c. 1410), [[Fabian von Auerswald]] (1462), [[Pietro Monte]] (c. 1480), and [[Hans Wurm]] (c. 1500).
It was only with the beginning [[Early Modern period]], specifically the more "dignified" code of behaviour the upper classes imposed on themselves in the [[Baroque period]] that wrestling was abandoned by European nobility, and it became a pastime of rural populations, developing into the various surviving forms of European [[folk wrestling]]. A late treatise on ''ringen'' is that by Johann Georg Passchen, published in 1659.<ref>''Vollständiges Ring-Buch / darinnen angewiesen wird / wie man Adversarium recht sol angreiffen / sich lossmachen / die schläge pariren / unterschiedliche Lectiones und die contra-Lectiones darauff machen / mit Fleiß beschrieben und mit vielen nothwendigen kupffern außgebildet.'' 1659, reprint 1663 Halle (S.), Melchior Oelschlägel; [http://jwma.ejmas.com/articles/2000/jwmaart_steenput_1200.html English translation by Eli Steenput], Journal of Western Martial Art, November 2000 [http://www.thearma.org/Manuals/Passchen/Passchen.htm]</ref> Maybe the last book which deals with Ringen as a deadly martial art, is possibly "Leib-beschirmende und Feinden Trotz-bietende Fecht-Kunst" from Johann Andreas Schmidt, which was published in Weigel, Nürnberg in 1713.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digital.bibliothek.uni-halle.de/hd/content/pageview/102714|title=343 [319] - Das VI. Capitul. - Seite - Inhouse-Digitalisierung|website=digital.bibliothek.uni-halle.de}}</ref> [[File:Antoin Sevruguin zoorkhaneh.jpg|thumb|Studio Portrait of Three Persian Wrestlers by [[Antoin Sevruguin]], c. 1890.]]
==In the Middle East== {{further|Varzesh-e Pahlavani}} Many of the world's oldest depictions of wrestling can be found in the Middle East. Carvings and statues show that forms of belt wrestling existed in the region since ancient times, in addition to matches between humans and animals. Wrestling is also mentioned in the epics of [[Gilgamesh]] and the [[Shahnameh]]. Oil wrestling as practiced in present-day Turkey and Central Asia is recorded in ancient Sumeria and Babylon. In Persia, Pahlavani traditional grappling or koshti (کشتی) was practiced by both the upper and lower classes both for sport and as training for battle. In training halls known as ''zourkhaneh'', soldiers practiced resistance exercises and grappling in a tradition now called [[Pahlevani and zoorkhaneh rituals|varzesh-e bastani]] (ورزش باستانی; lit. "ancient athletics"). Ancient Iranian combat-wrestling (''koshti-ye jangi'') included not only grabs but also punches and low kicks. As Iranian influence spread with the [[Achaemenid Empire]] and later the [[Persian Empire]], the practice was adopted in the [[Indian subcontient]] as [[pehlwani]].
==In Asia==
===China=== {{further|Shuai jiao}} Classical Chinese wrestling or ''jiao li'' (角力) was a public sport in the [[Qin Dynasty]] (221-207 BC) held for court amusement as well as for recruiting the best fighters. Competitors wrestled each other on a raised platform called a [[lei tai]]. The term ''shuai jiao'' was chosen by the [[Central Guoshu Academy]] of [[Nanjing]] in 1928 when competition rules began to be standardized. [[File:Shuai jiao wrestling.JPG|thumb|Two wrestlers, drawing of a detail of a [[Mogao Caves|Dunhuang fresco]], ca. 7th century.]]
===Indian subcontinent=== {{further|Malla-yuddha|Pehlwani}} Wrestling in the [[Indian subcontinent]] was differentiated into four types that progressed from sport (''malakride'') to combat (''[[malla-yuddha]]''). Mughal conquerors introduced more groundwork and referred to their grappling style as [[pehlwani|kusti]]. Competitors still wrestle as in ancient times, on dirt floors while wearing only [[kowpeenam]] or loincloth.
===Japan=== {{further|Jujitsu#History}} The term ''[[jūjutsu]]'' was coined in the 17th century, after which time it became a blanket term for a wide variety of grappling-related disciplines in [[Japanese martial arts]]. Prior to that time, these skills had names such as {{Nihongo|"short sword grappling"|小具足腰之廻|kogusoku koshi no mawari}}, {{Nihongo|"grappling"|組討 or 組打|kumiuchi}}, {{Nihongo|"body art"|体術|taijutsu}}, {{Nihongo|"softness"|柔 or 和|yawara}}, {{Nihongo|"art of harmony"|和術|wajutsu, ৳yawarajutsu}}, {{Nihongo|"catching hand"|捕手|torite}}, and even the {{Nihongo|"way of softness"|柔道|jūdō}} (as early as 1724, almost two centuries before Kanō Jigorō founded the modern art of Kodokan [[Judo]]).<ref name="classical_fighting_arts_of_japan">{{Citation | last1 = Mol | first1 = Serge | title = Classical Fighting Arts of Japan: A Complete Guide to Koryū Jūjutsu | year = 2001 | publisher = [[Kodansha International]] | location = Tokyo, Japan | isbn = 4-7700-2619-6 | pages = 24–54}}</ref> The systems of unarmed combat that were developed and practiced during the [[Muromachi period]] (before 1573) are today referred to collectively as {{Nihongo|Japanese old-style jujutsu|日本古流柔術|Nihon koryū jūjutsu}}.
==Modern history==
===Development of modern wrestling=== The [[Lancashire wrestling|Lancashire]] style of [[folk wrestling]] may have formed the basis for [[Catch wrestling]] also known as "catch as catch can." The [[Scottish people|Scots]] later formed a variant of this style, and the [[Ireland|Irish]] developed the "[[collar-and-elbow]]" style which later found its way into the United States.<ref name = 1190Poliakoff>{{cite book|last1=Poliakoff|first1=Michael|editor1-last=Levinson|editor1-first=David|editor2-last=Christensen|editor2-first=Karen|title=Encyclopedia of World Sport: From Ancient Times to the Present (Vol. 3)|date=1996|publisher=ABC-CLIO|location=Santa Barbara, CA|isbn=0-87436-819-7|pages=1190|chapter=Wrestling, Freestyle}}</ref>
Wrestling as a modern sport developed in the 19th century out of traditions of [[folk wrestling]], emerging in the form of two styles of regulated competitive sport, "[[Freestyle wrestling|freestyle]]" and "[[Greco-Roman wrestling#History|Greco-Roman]]" wrestling (based on British and continental tradition, respectively), now{{year needed|date=May 2014}} summarized under the term "[[amateur wrestling]]" by the beginning of the [[Olympic sport|modern Olympics]].
A tradition of combining wrestling and showmanship originates in [[July Monarchy|1830s France]], when showmen presented wrestlers under names such as “Edward, the steel eater”, “Gustave d’Avignon, the bone wrecker”, or “Bonnet, the ox of the low Alps” and challenged members of the public to knock them down for 500 [[French franc#French Empire and Restoration|franc]]s.<ref name="FILA">{{cite web|url=http://www.fila-official.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=14&Itemid=100246&lang=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011195312/http://fila-official.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=14&Itemid=100246&lang=en|dead-url=yes|archive-date=11 October 2011|title=Roots and history of Olympic wrestling|last=Anon|work=International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles|publisher=FILA|accessdate=2 August 2013}}</ref> In 1848, French showman, Jean Exbroyat formed the first modern wrestlers’ circus troupe and established a rule not to execute holds below the waist — a style he named "flat hand wrestling". This new style soon spread to the rest of Europe, the [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]], Italy, Denmark and Russia under the names of [[Greco-Roman wrestling]], Classic wrestling or French wrestling.
===Golden Age (1890–1914)=== {{anchor|Golden Age}} By the end of the 19th century, this modern "Greco-Roman" wrestling style went on to become the most in fashionable sport in Europe. Because of that and the rise of [[gymnasium (school)|gymnasiums]] and [[Sports club|athletic clubs]], Greco-Roman wrestling and modern freestyle wrestling were soon regulated in formal competitions. On continental Europe, prize money was offered in large sums to the winners of Greco-Roman tournaments, and freestyle wrestling spread rapidly in the United Kingdom and in the United States.
[[Image:Wrestling match during 1904 Summer Olympics.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Wrestling at the [[wrestling at the 1904 Summer Olympics|1904 Summer Olympics]].]] A "Golden Age" for the sport followed, cut short with the breakout of [[World War I]] in 1914. In 1898 the Frenchman [[Paul Pons|Paul Pons, “the Colossus”]] became the first Professional World Champion.<ref name="FILA"/><ref>{{Citation| last =[[International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles]]| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Greco-Roman Wrestling| work =| publisher =[[International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles|FILA]]| date =| url =http://www.fila-official.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=18&Itemid=36| format =| doi =| accessdate =2007-08-09| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110711000658/http://www.fila-official.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=18&Itemid=36| archivedate =2011-07-11| df =}} </ref> Leading wrestlers during this time, such as [[Georg Hackenschmidt]], [[Stanislaus Zbyszko]], [[William Muldoon]], [[Frank Gotch]], [[Constant Lavaux]], had the status of popular heroes.<ref name = 1190Poliakoff/><ref name = 1194Poliakoff>{{cite book|last1=Poliakoff|first1=Michael|editor1-last=Levinson|editor1-first=David|editor2-last=Christensen|editor2-first=Karen|title=Encyclopedia of World Sport: From Ancient Times to the Present (Vol. 3)|date=1996|publisher=ABC-CLIO|location=Santa Barbara, CA|isbn=0-87436-819-7|pages=1189–1193|chapter=Wrestling, Freestyle}}</ref>
In the United States, wrestling was dominated by [[Martin Burns|Martin "Farmer" Burns]] and his pupil, [[Frank Gotch]]. Burns was renowned as a competitive wrestler, who, despite never weighing more than 160 pounds during his wrestling career, fought over 6,000 wrestlers (at a time when most were competitive contests) and lost fewer than 10 of them.<ref name=hooker-ch3>{{cite book|last=Thesz|first=Lou|title=Hooker|chapter=Chapter 3}}</ref> He also gained a reputation for training some of the best wrestlers of the era, including Gotch, known as one of America's first sports superstars.<ref name=hooker-ch3/> Gotch, regarded as "peerless" at his peak, was the first to actually claim the world's undisputed heavyweight championship by beating all contenders in North America and Europe. He became the world's champion by beating European wrestling champion [[Georg Hackenschmidt]], both in 1908 and 1911, seen by modern wrestling historians as two of the most significant matches in wrestling history.
Professional wrestlers during this time would participate both in sportive competition and in shows focusing more on spectacle and entertainment, as wrestling was introduced to the public as part of a [[variety act]] to spice up the limited action involved in the bodybuilder [[High striker|strongman]] attractions. One of its earliest stars was a Cornish-American ex-miner named [[Jack Carkeek]], who would challenge audience members to last 10 minutes with him. It is in this period that the origin between the later division between "[[professional wrestling]]" (non-competitive acrobatics and showmanship) and "[[amateur wrestling]]" (competitive) originates. [[Georg Hackenschmidt]], world champion after his 1905 win over [[Tom Jenkins (wrestler)|Tom Jenkins]], associated himself with British promoter and entrepreneur Charles B. Cochran. Hackenschmidt took a series of bookings in [[Manchester]] for a then-impressive £150 a week. Noting Hackenschmidt's dominant style of wrestling threatened to kill crowd interest, Cochran persuaded Hackenschmidt to learn showmanship from Cannon and wrestle many of his matches for entertainment rather than sport; this displayed the future elements of [[sports entertainment]].
The separation of "[[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Work (noun)|worked]]", i.e. purely performative, choreographed wrestling from competitive sport begins in the 1920s. The success of the more [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Work (noun)|worked]] aspects of professional wrestling in America, like [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Gimmick|gimmickry]] and [[Professional wrestling holds|submission holds]], were introduced to British wrestling. Amateur wrestler, [[Atholl Oakley|Sir Atholl Oakley]] got together with fellow grappler Henry Irslinger to launch one of the first promotions to employ the new style of wrestling which was coined "[[All-in wrestling]]". The great demand for wrestling meant there were not enough skilled amateurs to go around, and many promoters switched to more [[Hardcore wrestling|violent styles]], with weapons and chairshots part of the proceedings. Women wrestlers and mud-filled rings also became commonplace. In the late 1930s, the [[London County Council]] banned professional wrestling.
When the [[1896 Olympics|First Modern Olympic Games]] held in [[Athens]] in 1896, Greco-Roman wrestling was introduced as an Olympic discipline. After not being featured in the [[1900 Olympics]], sports wrestling was seen again in 1904 in [[Saint Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]]; this time in freestyle competition. Since then, Greco-Roman and freestyle wrestling have both been featured (with women's freestyle added in the Summer Olympics of 2004).
===Interwar period and later 20th century=== The popularity of wrestling experienced a dramatic decline in 1915 to 1920, north due to the World War, and as its reputation had suffered especially among the American public because of widespread doubt of its legitimacy and status as a competitive sport.
Following the retirement of Frank Gotch, professional wrestling in the United States (except in the Midwest) was losing popularity fast. In response, three professional wrestlers, [[Ed Lewis (wrestler)|Ed Lewis]], [[Billy Sandow]], and [[Toots Mondt]], joined to form their own promotion in the 1920s, modifying their in-ring product to attract fans. The three were referred to as the "[[Gold Dust Trio]]" due to their financial success. This marks the beginning of "[[professional wrestling]]" as an entertainment industry separate from competitive wrestling, and to a revival of public interest in wrestling in the [[interwar period]]. Wrestling did not, however, rise to its pre-war level of popularity again, being eclipsed by [[Boxing]], which sport now experienced [[Boxing in the 1920s|its own Golden Age]].
Since 1921, the [[International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles|International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles (FILA)]] has regulated [[amateur wrestling]] as an athletic discipline. In 1927, [[Raymond G. Clapp|Dr. Raymond G. Clapp]] published the rules for [[collegiate wrestling]], and the next year, the first [[NCAA Wrestling Team Championship]] took place on March 30 to March 31 on the campus of [[Iowa State University|Iowa State College]]. The rules of collegiate wrestling marked a sharp contrast to the freestyle wrestling rules of the [[International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles|International Amateur Wrestling Federation]] (IAWF) and the [[Amateur Athletic Union|AAU]].<ref name="1191Poliakoff" /> From then on, collegiate wrestling emerged as a distinctly American sport. College and high school wrestling grew especially after the standardization of the NCAA wrestling rules, which applied early on to both collegiate and scholastic wrestling (with high school modifications). More colleges, universities, and junior colleges began offering dual meets and tournaments, including championships and having organized wrestling seasons. There were breaks in wrestling seasons because of [[World War II]], but in the high schools especially, state association wrestling championships sprung up in different regions throughout the 1930s and 1940s. As amateur wrestling grew after World War II, various collegiate athletic conferences also increased the number and quality of their wrestling competition, with more wrestlers making the progression of wrestling in high school, being recruited by college coaches, and then entering the collegiate competition.
[[File:Davangere Wrestlers.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Pehlwani]]-style wrestling match in [[Davangere]], [[Karnataka, India]] (2005).]] Both [[freestyle wrestling]] and its American counterpart, [[collegiate wrestling]], did not have a scoring system that decided matches in the absence of a fall until the introduction of a point system by [[Oklahoma State University]] wrestling coach [[Art Griffith]] that gained acceptance in 1941, and influenced the international styles as well. By the 1960s international wrestling matches in Greco-Roman and freestyle were scored by a panel of three judges in secret, who made the final decision by raising colored paddles at the match's end. [[Albert de Ferrari|Dr. Albert de Ferrari]] from [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]] who became vice president of FILA, lobbied for a visible scoring system and a rule for "controlled fall", which would recognize a fall only when the offensive wrestler had done something to cause it. These were soon adopted internationally in Greco-Roman and freestyle.<ref>{{cite web |last=Dellinger |first=Bob |authorlink=Bob Dellinger |coauthors= |title=The Oldest Sport |work= |publisher=[[National Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]] |date= |url=http://www.wrestlinghalloffame.org/history/oldestsport.php |format= |doi= |accessdate=2007-08-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703010121/http://www.wrestlinghalloffame.org/history/oldestsport.php |archivedate=2007-07-03 |deadurl=yes |df= }} </ref>
==Notes== {{notelist}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Orphan|date=April 2018}}
'''Hector Solis Flores''' (born September 2, 1985) is a famous Mexican entrepreneur and local celebrity. Solis was born in [[Mexico City]] to Hector Solis and Milagro Flores.
==Early years==
Hector Solis moved from Mexico City to [[Guadalajara, Jalisco|Guadalajara]] at the age of 2. He studied at the [[Franco Mexicano]] where he learned French. This opened the doors to the world of celebrities and fashion. Thanks to his French, he studied in the [[ESCP]] where he met [[Zinedine Zidane]] who introduced him to the sports environment. He is now a partner of [[Gerardo Arturo González Sü]].
==External links== * [http://www.hattrick.org/ Hattrick]

revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Infinity Park | nickname = | logo_image = | image = [[File:Infinity Park 4 by 3 ver 2.jpg|240px]] | location = 4500 E. Kentucky Ave.
Glendale, CO 80246 | coordinates = {{coord|39.6992|-104.9349|type:landmark_region:US-CO|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 2007 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | former_names = | tenants = [[Glendale Raptors]] ([[Major League Rugby|MLR]]) (2018–present)
[[Glendale Merlins]] (2007–present)
[[Denver Barbarians RFC|Denver Barbarians]] (PRP) (2014–present)
[[Denver Stampede]] ([[PRO Rugby|PRO]]) (April – May 2016) | seating_capacity = 5,000 (rugby) | dimensions = 100m x 68m |}} '''Infinity Park''' is a sports stadium in the [[Denver]] enclave of [[Glendale, Colorado]], and was formerly the unofficial home stadium of the [[United States national rugby union team]]. The stadium has a seating capacity of 5,000 people. The stadium opened in 2007, at a cost of $22.5 million.[http://calendar.denverpost.com/glendale-co/venues/show/318575-infinity-park Article on Infinity Park], ''Denver Post''. It is the first rugby-specific, municipally-owned stadium in the United States.Rainbird, [http://www.rainbird.com/documents/turf/site_InfinityPark-GlendaleCO.pdf "Site Report Infinity Park and Infinity Park South"]''Denver Post'', [http://www.denverpost.com/search/ci_7010492 "Glendale's ambition soars on raucous rugby"], September 27, 2007. Infinity Park is the venue for several domestic rugby teams. The rugby stadium is home to the [[Glendale Raptors]], a professional [[rugby union]] team in [[Major League Rugby]], the [[Glendale Merlins]], a Division I men's rugby team that have won the national championship[https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS20660+12-Apr-2008+PRN20080412 Glendale Raptors End Season Unbeaten], Reuters., and of the [[Denver Barbarians RFC|Denver Barbarians]]. The stadium also hosts the Women's Premier League's Glendale Lady Raptors.[http://rugbymag.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2877:raptors-replace-valks-in-12-wpl&catid=60:womens-clubs&Itemid=232 "raptors-replace-valks-in-12"], Rugby Mag. The [[Denver Stampede]] of the now defunct [[PRO Rugby]] played at the stadium between April and May 2016. Infinity Park also hosts various tournaments. The stadium regularly hosts [[USA Rugby]] national men's club semifinals and finals championships. Infinity Park is the home of the [[Waisale Serevi|Serevi]] Rugbytown Sevens Tournament which takes place in August each year and attracts teams from around the world to compete for a winner-take-all $10,000 cash prize. Most notably, it became the new home of the [[USA Women's Sevens]], the country's stop in the annual [[World Rugby Women's Sevens Series]], starting with the [[2018–19 World Rugby Women's Sevens Series|2018–19 season]].{{cite press release|url=https://www.worldrugby.org/news/348421 |title=Schedule confirmed for HSBC World Rugby Sevens Series 2019 |publisher=World Rugby |date=July 7, 2018 |accessdate=August 6, 2018}} ==International rugby== Infinity Park has hosted international rugby test matches. It hosted the 2009 and 2010 [[Churchill Cup]], an international rugby tournament involving the United States, Canada, England, France, Argentina and other countries. It has also been the venue for various international test matches, such as the August 2011 United States v. Canada match, which sold out; and the [[2012 mid-year rugby test series|June 2012]] United States v. [[Georgia national rugby union team|Georgia]] match. ==College rugby== Infinity Park has also hosted various [[college rugby]] championships and other matches. Infinity Park has hosted the men's collegiate all-stars (2008-2011). The stadium has also hosted Division I college rugby matches played by the [[Colorado Buffaloes|University of Colorado]] and [[Colorado State Rams|Colorado State University]].RugbyRugby, Feb. 28, 2012, [http://rugbyrugby.com/news/more_news/college_rugby/7000404/csu_vs_cu_sat_infinity_park_4pm "CSU vs CU Sat Infinity Park 4pm"] The venue has also hosted the [[NSCRO Champions Cup|Champions Cup]] of the [[National Small College Rugby Organization]] (NSCRO).RugbyRugby, March 27, 2012, [http://www.rugbyrugby.com/news/more_news/college_rugby/7001416/time_to_ruck_n_roll_on_the_road_to_infinity_park "Time to Ruck'n'Roll on the Road to Infinity Park"] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Glendale Raptors}} {{World Rugby Women's Sevens Series}} [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Denver]] [[Category:Major League Rugby stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues in Denver]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2007]] [[Category:2007 establishments in Colorado]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Arapahoe County, Colorado]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Haifa Municipal Stadium
{{Hebrew|אצטדיון העירוני חיפה}} | nickname = Kiryat Eliezer
{{Hebrew|קריית אליעזר}} | image = Haifa-WM01 - Kiryat Eliezer Stadium during a local derby.jpg | image_size = 250px | fullname = | location = 16 Tzahal Street, Kiryat Eliezer, [[Haifa]] 35157 | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1955 | built = | opened = 1955 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 2014 | demolished = 2015 | owner = [[Haifa|Municipality of Haifa]] | operator = ETHOS | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Hapoel Haifa F.C.|Hapoel Haifa]] (1955–2014)
[[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] (1955–2014) | seating_capacity = 14,002 | dimensions = }} The '''Haifa Municipal Stadium''' ({{lang-he-n|אצטדיון העירוני חיפה}}, ''Etztadion HaIroni Haifa''), more commonly known as '''Kiryat Eliezer''' ({{Hebrew|קריית אליעזר}}), was a multi-use [[stadium]] in the [[Kiryat Eliezer, Haifa|Kiryat Eliezer]] neighborhood of [[Haifa]], [[Israel]]. It was mostly used for [[association football|football]] matches and as the home stadium of [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] and [[Hapoel Haifa FC|Hapoel Haifa]]. It was replaced by the new [[Sammy Ofer Stadium]] at the southern entrance to the city in 2014. ==Background== The stadium was built in 1955, as a gift from the [[Italian Labour Union]]. It seats 14,002 among its 14 gates. Ownership of the stadium belonged to the [[Haifa|Municipality of Haifa]], though it was managed by a suborganization called ETHOS. The stadium was officially opened on 14 September 1955, with a match between Haifa XI and Tel Aviv XI.[http://archive.football.org.il/multimedia/PDF/Newspapers/hadashot/1955/09-15-1955.pdf Haifa–Tel Aviv 3:3] Hadshot HaSport, 15 September 1955, p. 11 {{he icon}} On 24 September 1955 the first [[Haifa derby]] was played at the stadium, with Maccabi beating Hapoel 4-1.[http://archive.football.org.il/multimedia/PDF/Newspapers/hadashot/1955/09-25-1955.pdf The Haifa Derby Was Settled Within 25 Minutes] Hadshot HaSport, 25 September 1955, p. 8 {{he icon}} Both clubs had previously played at [[Thomas D'Alesandro Stadium|Kiryat Haim Stadium]] in the [[HaKerayot|Kerayot]] area of [[Haifa]]. The first match played at the stadium, while it was being built, was held during the [[Football at the 1953 Maccabiah Games|1953 Maccabiah Games]], between Israel and Finland.[http://jhpress.nli.org.il/Default/Scripting/ArticleWin.asp?From=Archive&Source=Page&Skin=TAUHe&BaseHref=DAV/1953/10/02&PageLabelPrint=&EntityId=Ar02200&ViewMode=HTML Stadium on the Way] Davar, 2 October 1953, Historical Jewish Press {{he icon}} The stadium did not meet [[UEFA]]'s highest standards forcing the clubs in [[Haifa]] to host their European matches in the [[Tel Aviv]] area. At certain times, UEFA also has limited clubs from outside the Tel Aviv area from hosting even low level European qualifiers citing security concerns. Kiryat Eliezer was the only stadium in [[Israel]] equipped with electronic gates in an effort to curb scalping and the sale of counterfeit tickets. Regulars to the stadium could have purchased a card for 10 [[New Israeli Sheqel|shekels]], which can be refilled for specific matches held at the stadium. There was one scoreboard in the stadium, which did not had a replay screen. The only television in the stadium, outside of the television broadcast booth, was in front of the seat of [[Ya'akov Shahar]], the owner of Maccabi Haifa. Only the A section of the stadium was covered by a roof. The last game in the stadium was played on 14 May 2014, with Maccabi Haifa hosting Maccabi Tel Aviv in the Israeli Premier League. ==Transportation== The stadium was located in the Kiryat Eliezer neighborhood of [[Haifa]]. Adjacent to the stadium is Beit [[Egged Bus Cooperative|Egged]]. Thus the stadium was easily served by all [[Egged Bus Cooperative|Egged]] bus lines running into and out of [[Haifa]] as well as the [[Haifa Bat Galim Railway Station|Bat Galim Railway Station]], which is a central stop for all train lines running up the coast of the [[Mediterranean Sea]]. ==Gates== [[Image:Qiryat Eliezer Stadium Facade.jpg|thumb|right|Outside the stadium]] [[Image:Kiryat Eliezer Stadium05.jpg|thumb|right|VIP Section at Kiryat Eliezer]] {| class="wikitable" border="1" ! Area ! Gate ! Capacity |- | A | 1 | 1003 |- bgcolor="#EFEFEF" | A | 2 | 1283 |- | A | VIP Section | 548 |- bgcolor="#EFEFEF" | A | 4 | 1528 |- | A | 5A | 721 |- bgcolor="#EFEFEF" | A | 5B | 831 |- | B | 6 | 466 |- bgcolor="#EFEFEF" | B | 7 | 807 |- | B | 8 | 475 |- bgcolor="#EFEFEF" | A | Press Box | 52 |- | C | 9 | 834 |- bgcolor="#EFEFEF" | C | 10 | 850 |- | C | 11 | 944 |- bgcolor="#EFEFEF" | C | 12 | 958 |- | C | 13 | 1082 |- bgcolor="#EFEFEF" | C | 14 | 954 |- | '''Total''' | '''14''' | '''14002''' |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{portal|Association football|Israel}} {{Commons category|Kiryat Eliezer Stadium}} *[http://www.haifa.muni.il/ Municipality of Haifa] *[http://www.ethos.co.il/ ETHOS] - Organization for the Arts, Culture and Sport, Haifa Inc. *[http://www.garber-tickets.co.il/ Garber Tickets] - Ticket agent for events at Kiryat Eliezer *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130128073406/http://maccabi-haifafc.walla.co.il/ Official website of Maccabi Haifa] *[http://www.hapoel-haifa.co.il/ Official website of Hapoel Haifa] {{Hapoel Haifa F.C.}} {{Maccabi Haifa F.C.}} {{coord|32.827322|34.981284|display=title|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:4000}} [[Category:Sports venues in Haifa]] [[Category:Defunct football venues in Israel]] [[Category:Hapoel Haifa F.C.]] [[Category:Maccabi Haifa F.C.]] [[Category:AFC Asian Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1956]]

revision.text:
{{Spanish name|Riquelme|Frutos}} {{Infobox model | name = Larissa Riquelme | image = LarissaRiquelme01.JPG | imagesize = 250px | caption = Larissa Riquelme in 2010 | alt = | alias = | birth_name = Larissa Mabel Riquelme Frutos | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1985|02|22|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Asunción]], [[Paraguay]] | occupation = {{hlist|Model|actress}} | years_active = 2010 - present | death_date = | death_place = | height = {{height|m=1.70}} | haircolor = Brown | eyecolor = Brown | agency = | spouse = | partner = [[Jonathan Fabbro]] {{small|(2013-present)}} | relatives = | website = }}
'''Larissa Mabel Riquelme Frutos''' (born 22 February 1985) is a [[Paraguay|Paraguayan]] [[model (person)|model]] and [[actress]] from [[Asunción]]. She is one of the highest-paid models in Paraguay.<ref name="globo">{{cite web |url=http://ego.globo.com/Gente/Noticias/0,,MUL1604459-9798,00-MUSA+DA+COPA+LARISSA+RIQUELME+E+A+MODELO+MAIS+BEM+PAGA+DO+PARAGUAI.html|title=Musa da Copa, Larissa Riquelme é a modelo mais bem paga do Paraguai |accessdate=2010-07-08 |date=2010-07-05 |work=[[O Globo]] |publisher=globo.com}}</ref>
==Biography== A famous model and actress in Paraguay, Riquelme rose to international prominence during the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]].<ref name="peck">{{cite web |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/soccer-dirty-tackle/larissa-riquelme-incredibly-popular-reason--soccer.html |title=Larissa Riquelme is incredibly popular for some reason |accessdate=2010-07-03 |last=Peck |first=Brooks |date=2010-06-30 |work=Dirty Tackle |publisher=Yahoo.com}}</ref> A supporter of both the [[Paraguay national football team]] and the club [[Cerro Porteño]], she was first pictured in international media celebrating a goal during the game between Paraguay and [[Slovakia]] with her [[Nokia]] mobile phone between her [[breasts]] and she was wearing a T-shirt with Paraguay's colors (as part of a promotion for a mobile phone company<ref name="peck"/>). Riquelme is the face of the deodorant brand [[Axe (grooming product)|Axe]] in Paraguay<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.axe.com.py |title=Homepage of Axe in Paraguay |accessdate=2010-07-08 |work=Axe Paraguay |publisher=axe.compy}}</ref> and at a later Paraguay game in the World Cup she was also seen with the word "Axe" written on her chest as advertising for the deodorant brand.<ref name="metro">{{cite news |title=Lingerie model Larissa Riquelme to strip naked despite Paraguay defeat |newspaper=[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]] |date=2010-07-05 |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/sport/football/834040-lingerie-model-larissa-riquelme-to-strip-naked-despite-paraguay-defeat |accessdate=2010-07-05 }}</ref>
After becoming one of the most searched people on the Internet,<ref>{{cite web |last=Phillips|first=Tom |title=World Cup Superfan Larissa Riquelme To Run From The Police Naked If Paraguay Wins |url= http://bleacherreport.com/articles/413240-world-cup-wag-larissa-riquelme-to-run-naked-if-paraguay-wins#page/1 |work=Bleacher Report |accessdate=22 July 2010}}</ref> she was named "World Cup's Girlfriend" by ''[[Diario Marca|Marca]]'', the largest Spanish sports newspaper.<ref name="gracias">{{cite web |url=http://www.marca.com/blogs/el-otro-mundial/2010/07/02/larissa-riquelme-gracias-a-marca-por.html |title=Larissa Riquelme: "Gracias a Marca por bautizarme 'novia del mundial'" |accessdate=2010-07-04 |date=2010-07-02 |work=[[Diario Marca|Marca]] |publisher=Marca.com}}</ref> She was also described as the most famous fan of the World Cup.<ref name="gracias"/>
Following her rise to fame, and after Argentinian coach [[Diego Maradona]] promised to run naked through [[Buenos Aires]] if Argentina won the 2010 World Cup, Riquelme matched the offer and promised that she would run naked (wearing only [[body paint]] in the colors of Paraguay) through [[Asunción]] if [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]] won the World Cup, or even if they reached the semi-finals by beating Spain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianews.org.in/paraguay-can-make-larissa-riquelmes-dream-come-true/archives/1676 |title=Paraguay can make Larissa Riquelme’s dream come true |accessdate=2010-07-03 |date=2010-07-03 |work=Game On! |publisher=indianews.org.in |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706065827/http://www.indianews.org.in/paraguay-can-make-larissa-riquelmes-dream-come-true/archives/1676 |archivedate=July 6, 2010 }}</ref> Paraguay eventually lost its match against Spain, but Riquelme announced that she would fulfill her promise anyway,<ref name="metro"/> a promise that she kept.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/sport/oddballs/834495-larissa-riquelme-strips-naked-for-paraguay-as-promised |title=Model Larissa Riquelme strips naked for Paraguay - as promised |accessdate=2011-07-05 |date=2010-07-08 |work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |publisher=metro.co.uk}}</ref> That same year, Riquelme did a nude pictorial for the September 2010 issue of ''[[Playboy magazine (Brazilian issue)|Playboy Brazil]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ego.globo.com/Gente/Noticias/0,,MUL1609138-9798,00-LARISSA+RIQUELME+ASSINA+CONTRATO+COM+A+PLAYBOY+E+SERA+CAPA+DE+SETEMBRO.html |title=Larissa Riquelme assina contrato com a 'Playboy' e será capa de setembro |publisher=[[Rede Globo|EGO]] |date=2010-07-26|language=Portuguese|accessdate=2011-07-17}}</ref>
Apart from modeling and acting, Riquelme has also participated in ''Bailando por un Sueño'', the Argentinian version of ''[[Dancing with the Stars]].''<ref name="globo"/>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
{{Sister project links|wikt=no |commons=Category:Larissa Riquelme|d=no |b=no |n=no |q=no |s=no |v=no |species=no}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Riquelme, Larissa}} [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Paraguayan female models]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:People from Asunción]] [[Category:2010 FIFA World Cup]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]]

{{National rugby union | unionname = Malta Rugby Football Union | nativename = | logo = Malta Rugby Football Union Logo.jpg | founded = 1991 | IRB = 2000 | region = [[FIRA - Association of European Rugby|FIRA]] | regionyear = 2000 | patron = | president = Steve Busuttil | coach = Damian Neill | womenscoach = | countryflag = Malta | url = [http://www.maltarugby.com/ www.maltarugby.com] }}
The '''Malta Rugby Football Union''' ('''MRFU''') is the governing body for all [[Rugby Union]] in [[Malta]]. The MRFU is a full member of [[Rugby Europe]] and [[World Rugby]]. The MRFU is a member of SportMalta, the Maltese islands national sports body.
On September 14, 2016, Steve Busuttil defeated the incumbent Brian Dalton in the election for President of the Union.<ref>https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20160914/sport/Busuttil-elected-new-president-of-the-MRFU.624987</ref>
The Board of the Union is as follows:
*President: Steve Busuttil. *Vice-President: N/A *Secretary General: Steve Ganado *Treasurer: Audrey Vella *PRO: George Zammit Montebello
==See also== * [[Rugby union in Malta]] * [[Malta national rugby union team]]

Atkinson Company | tenants = [[Oakland Raiders]] ([[American Football League|AFL]]/[[National Football League|NFL]]) (1966–1981, 1995–present)
[[Oakland Athletics]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]) (1968–present)
[[Oakland Clippers]] ([[National Professional Soccer League (1967)|NPSL]]/[[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|NASL]]) (1967–1968)
[[Oakland Stompers]] ([[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|NASL]]) (1978)
[[Oakland Invaders]] ([[United States Football League|USFL]]) (1983–1985)
[[San Jose Earthquakes]] ([[Major League Soccer|MLS]]) (2008–2009){{cite press release |title=Official Statements Concerning the Cancellation of Grand Prix of Arizona|url=http://www.champcarworldseries.com/News/Article.asp?ID=12147|publisher=Champ Car World Series|date=September 15, 2007|accessdate=September 15, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927213717/http://www.champcarworldseries.com/News/Article.asp?ID=12147|archivedate=September 27, 2007}} | website = {{URL|http://www.coliseum.com}} }} [[File:1984 Mother's Cookies - Oakland Coliseum.JPG|thumb|right|250px|The Coliseum as seen in its original open grandstand configuration before being enclosed.]]}} The '''Oakland–Alameda County Coliseum''', often referred to as the '''Oakland Coliseum''', is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Oakland, California]], United States, which is home to both the [[Oakland Athletics]] of [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) and the [[Oakland Raiders]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL). It opened in 1966 and is the only remaining stadium in the United States that is shared by professional football and baseball teams. The Coliseum was also home to some games of the [[San Jose Earthquakes]] of [[Major League Soccer]] in 2008–2009 and hosted games at the [[2009 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. The Oakland–Alameda County Coliseum complex consists of the stadium and the neighboring [[Oracle Arena]]. The Coliseum has 6,300 club seats, 2,700 of which are available for Athletics games, 143 luxury suites, 125 of which are available for Athletics games, and a variable [[seating capacity]] of 47,170 for baseball, 56,057 for football, and 63,132 for [[Association football|soccer]]. In seating capacity, Oakland Coliseum is the second [[List of current National Football League stadiums|smallest NFL stadium]], larger only than [[StubHub Center]], the temporary home of the [[Los Angeles Chargers]], but the eighth [[List of Major League Baseball stadiums|largest MLB stadium]]. On April 3, 2017, Opening Day, the Athletics dedicated the Coliseum's playing surface as '''Rickey Henderson Field''' in honor of [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|MLB Hall of Famer]] and former Athletic [[Rickey Henderson]]. ==Stadium history== ===Design=== The Coliseum features an underground design where the playing surface is actually below ground level (21 feet/6 meters below sea level). Consequently, fans entering the stadium find themselves walking on to the main concourse of the stadium at the top of the first level of seats. This, combined with the hill that was built around the stadium to create the upper concourse, means that only the third deck is visible from outside the park. This gives the Coliseum the illusion of being a short stadium from the outside. ===Planning and construction=== Business and political leaders in Oakland had long been in competition with neighbor San Francisco, as well as other cities in the West, and worked for Oakland and its suburbs (the greater [[East Bay (San Francisco Bay Area)|East Bay]]) to be recognized nationally as a viable metropolitan area with its own identity and reputation, distinct and separate from that of San Francisco. Professional sports was seen as a primary way for the East Bay to gain such recognition. As a result, the desire for a major-league caliber stadium in the city of Oakland intensified during the 1950s and 1960s.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} By 1960, a non-profit corporation was formed to oversee the financing and development of the facility (rather than city or county government issuing taxpayer-backed bonds for construction). Local real estate developer Robert T. Nahas headed this group (which included other prominent East Bay business leaders such as former US Senator [[William Knowland]] and Edgar F. Kaiser), which later became the governing board of the Coliseum upon completion. It was Nahas' idea that the Coliseum be privately financed with ownership transferring to the city and county upon retirement of the construction financing.''Oakland Tribune'', November 3, 1960, front page Robert T. Nahas served 20 years as President of the Oakland–Alameda County Coliseum Board. On the death of Nahas, the ''San Francisco Chronicle'''s Rick DelVecchio quoted Jack Maltester, a former [[San Leandro, California|San Leandro]] mayor and Coliseum board member, "If not for Bob Nahas, there would be no Coliseum, it's really that simple." Nahas had to be a diplomat dealing with the egos of Raiders owner [[Al Davis]], Athletics owner [[Charles O. Finley]], and Warriors owner [[Franklin Mieuli]]. Preliminary architectural plans were unveiled in November 1960, and the following month a site was chosen west of the [[Elmhurst, Oakland, California|Elmhurst]] district of East Oakland alongside the then-recently completed [[Interstate 880|Nimitz Freeway]]. A downtown site adjacent to [[Lake Merritt]] and the Oakland Auditorium (which itself, many years later, would be renamed the [[Kaiser Convention Center|Henry J. Kaiser Convention Center]]) was also originally considered. The [[Port of Oakland]] played a key role in the East Oakland site selection; The Port swapped {{convert|157|acre}} at the head of San Leandro Bay to the [[East Bay Regional Park District]], in exchange for {{convert|105|acre}} of park land across the freeway, which the Port in turn donated to the City of Oakland as the site for the Coliseum sports complex.{{cite web |title=Chapter 2 – LWVO Study|url=http://www.waterfrontaction.org/learn/league/ch2.htm|publisher=Waterfront Action|accessdate=July 16, 2013}} The [[Oakland Raiders]] of the [[American Football League]] moved to [[Frank Youell Field]], a makeshift stadium near [[downtown Oakland]], in 1962, and the Coliseum was already being heralded in the local media as the Raiders' future permanent home. Baseball was also a major factor in the planning of the Coliseum. As early as {{MLBy|1961}}, the [[American League]] publicly indicated that it wished to include Oakland in its West Coast expansion plans. In {{MLBy|1963}}, American League president [[Joe Cronin]] suggested that Coliseum officials model some aspects of the new ballpark after then-new [[Dodger Stadium]], which impressed him,''Oakland Tribune'', January 27, 1963, pg. 39E though these expansion plans seemed to fade by the middle of the decade. After approval from the city of Oakland as well as Alameda County by 1962, $25 million in financing was arranged. Plans were drawn for a stadium, an [[Oracle Arena|indoor arena]], and an exhibition hall in between them. The architect of record was the San Francisco office of [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] (with [[Myron Goldsmith]] the principal design architect{{cite news|title=Myron Goldsmith -- Noted Architect|first=Allan|last=Temko|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Myron-Goldsmith-Noted-Architect-2974662.php|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=July 17, 1996|accessdate=March 8, 2016}}) and the general contractor was Guy F. Atkinson Company. Preliminary site preparation began in the summer of 1961. Construction began in the spring of 1962. The construction schedule was delayed for two years due to various legal issues and cost overruns; the original design of the Coliseum had to be modified slightly in order to stay on budget.''Oakland Tribune'', April 3, 1964, page E49 (For details on the indoor arena, now known as Oracle Arena, refer to that facility's article.) In {{MLBy|1965}}, it was rumored that the [[Cleveland Indians]] might leave Cleveland for a West Coast city (such as Oakland), but the Indians ended up remaining in Cleveland. [[Charlie Finley]], owner of the [[Kansas City Athletics]], unhappy in Kansas City, impressed by Oakland's new stadium and personally convinced to consider Oakland by Nahas,{{cite news |title=Robert Nahas -- He Brought Coliseum and A's to Oakland|first=Rick|last=DelVecchio|url=https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Robert-Nahas-He-brought-Coliseum-and-A-s-to-2870795.php|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=February 26, 2002|accessdate=September 5, 2018}} eventually got permission after several unsuccessful attempts and amid considerable controversy, to relocate his American League franchise to the stadium for the {{MLBy|1968}} season (for details on the controversy, see the separate articles for the A's and the [[Kansas City Royals]], the expansion franchise created to replace the A's in Kansas City). ===Configurations=== In its baseball configuration, the Coliseum has the most foul territory of any ballpark in Major League Baseball. Thus, many balls that would reach the seats in other ballparks can be caught for outs at the Coliseum. The distance to the backstop was initially {{convert|90|ft|m}}, but was reduced to {{convert|60|ft|m}} in 1969. From 1968 through 1981 and in 1995, two football configurations were used at the stadium. During Raider preseason games and all regular season games played while the baseball season was still going on, the field was set up from home plate to center field (east/west). Seats that were down the foul lines for baseball games became the sideline seats for football games, which started up to 120 feet away from the field (most football-only stadiums have sideline seats that start around 60 feet away). Once the A's season ended, the orientation was switched to north/south: i.e. the football field ran from the left field line to the right field line; seats were moved from behind first and third base to create corners for the end zone to fit into (these seats were then placed to fill in the space that was normally behind home plate and near the foul poles for baseball games). Temporary football bleachers were then added in front of the baseball bleachers to form the sideline on the east (visitors') side, and the baseball bleachers were not sold. Raiders season ticket holders would thus have two season ticket locations in different parts of the stadium that roughly corresponded to the same location in relation to the field. Since stadium expansion in 1996, the field has run north/south throughout the season. ===Seating capacity=== {| class="wikitable" style="float:left; margin-right:1em" |+ Baseball |- ! scope="col" style="{{Baseball primary style|Oakland Athletics}};"|Years ! scope="row" style="{{Baseball secondary style|Oakland Athletics}};"|1983–1984 | style="text-align:center;" | 50,219 |- ! scope="row" style="{{Baseball secondary style|Oakland Athletics}};"|1985 | style="text-align:center;" | 50,255 |- ! scope="row" style="{{Baseball secondary style|Oakland Athletics}};"|1988 | style="text-align:center;" | 50,219 |- ! scope="row" style="{{Baseball secondary style|Oakland Athletics}};"|1989 | style="text-align:center;" | 49,219 |- ! scope="row" style="{{Baseball secondary style|Oakland Athletics}};"|1990 | style="text-align:center;" | 48,219 |- ! scope="row" style="{{Baseball secondary style|Oakland Athletics}};"|1991 | style="text-align:center;" | 47,450 |- !
